question:
With reference to Indian National Movement, consider the following pairs: (UPSC Prelims 2019)

Person

Position held

1. Sir Tej Bahadur

 President, All India Sapru Liberal Federation

2. K. C.    Neogy

Member, The Constituent Assembly

3. P. C.Joshi

General Secretary, Communist Party of India

Which of the pairs given above is/are correctly matched?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1 and 2 only
option_3: 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru (1875 - 1949) was the leader of the Liberal party in British ruled India. He was a lawyer, politician, and freedom fighter who helped draft the Indian Constitution. He also collaborated with Congress on several freedom movements, including the Quit India, Salt Satyagraha, and Non-Cooperation Movements.
  • In 1945, Sapru’s Sapru Committee Report recommended the establishment of a constitution-making body that would equally represent Muslims and Hindus. The report also rejected separate electorates for Muslims and instead proposed joint electorates with reserved seats.
  • Kshitish Chandra Neogy (1888–1970), also known as KC Neogy, was an Indian politician from West Bengal. He was a member of the Constituent Assemblyof India, member of the first Cabinet of independent India and the chairman of the first Finance Commission of India.
  • Puran Chand Joshi was the general secretary of the Communist Party of India (CPI) from 1935 to 1947. Joshi was an early leader of India’s communist movement. In December 1947, the leftist group around BTR won control over the CPI’s Central Committee.

question:
With reference to the history of India, consider the following pairs: (UPSC Prelims 2020)

1. Aurang - In-charge of treasury of the State

2. Banian - Indian agent of the East India Company

3. Mirasidar - Designated revenue payer to the State

Which of the pairs given above is/are correctly matched?
option_1: 1 and 2 only
option_2: 2 and 3 only
option_3: 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Aurang is a Persian term that refers to a warehouse or workshop. It is a place where goods are collected before being sold.
  • In the 1820s, many warehouses or aurangs of Indian woven cloth were abolished as British textiles became more competitive.
  • Banians (banias) were agents of the company. “A Banyan is a person by whom the English gentlemen in general conduct all their business.
  • He is interpreter, head book-keeper, head secretary, head broker, the supplier of cash and cash-keeper, and in general also secretkeeper.
  • In the history of India, a mirasidar is a landholder or landlord who is responsible for collecting and paying revenue to the state. Mirasidars are designated revenue payers to the state, particularly in the Tamil regions of South India.
  • Mirasidars have hereditary rights to the land, known as mirasi rights. Under the ryotwari settlement system, the government recognizes mirasidars as the sole proprietors of land, dismissing tenants’ rights.
  • Mirasidars were responsible for collecting revenue from a particular area and paying it to the state during the Mughal period.
  • Mirasidars are a handful of village elites who often belong to Brahman and other high castes. They assert their rights of ownership over the land of the entire village and control village affairs.

question: Which of the following statements correctly explain the impact of the Industrial Revolution on India during the first half of the nineteenth century? (UPSC Prelims 2020)
option_1: Indian handicrafts were ruined.
option_2: Machines were introduced in the Indian textile industry in large numbers.
option_3: Railway lines were laid in many parts of the country
option_4: Heavy duties were imposed on the imports of British manufactures
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

The Industrial Revolution in India :

  • It began in the mid-19th century, during British colonial rule. It was primarily focused on the textile industry, with the establishment of mills and factories in cities like Mumbai and Ahmedabad.
  • The Industrial Revolution was a period of scientific and technological development in the 18th century that transformed largely rural, agrarian societies into industrialized, urban ones. The invention of machines reduced the need for manpower and led to the development of the factory system.

Factors that led to the Industrial Revolution in India include:

1. Growing demand

2. Availability of raw materials

3. Advancements in transportation

4. British colonial rule

  • The Industrial Revolution entered India in 1854 when Bombay opened its first steam powered cotton mill in Asia. Initially, the growth was slow, and the expansion of these modernised cotton mills was not done until the 1870s and 1880s.
  • Industrialization is the process of transforming the economy of a nation or region from a focus on agriculture to a reliance on manufacturing. Mechanized methods of mass production are an essential component of this transition.

The Industrial Revolution had many impacts on India in the first half of the nineteenth century:

1. Handicrafts :

The influx of cheap, machine-made British goods into the Indian market severely impacted the traditional Indian handicrafts industry. Indian artisans could not compete with the price and volume of goods produced by the mechanized industries of Britain. Handloom weavers in India suffered greatly due to this.

2. Textiles :

Indian textiles now had to face stiff competition from English textiles in the European and American markets. Heavy duties were imposed on imported Indian textiles in Britain.

3. New industries :

New industries also started emerging in India, such as cotton and jute mills, iron and steel plants, chemical plants, cement plants, and mining industries

question: Indigo cultivation in India declined by the beginning of the 20th century because of............. (UPSC Prelims 2020)
option_1: Peasant resistance to the oppressive conduct of planters
option_2: Its unprofitability in the world market because of new inventions
option_3: National leaders’ opposition to the cultivation of indigo
option_4: Government control over the planters
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The correct answer is (b)
  • Its unprofitability in the world market because of new inventions.
  • By the beginning of the 20th century, Indigo cultivation in India declined mainly because of the invention of synthetic indigo (artificial indigo) in Germany.
  • The German chemist Adolf von Baeyer successfully synthesized indigo dye in the late 19th century, and by the early 1900s, large-scale industrial production in Europe made synthetic indigo much cheaper than natural indigo obtained from Indian plantations.
  • As a result, the global demand for natural indigo drastically fell, making its cultivation commercially unprofitable for both planters and peasants in India.
  • Although peasant resistance to the oppressive conduct of planters and government control played a role earlier (like during the Indigo Revolt of 1859–60), the main cause of the final decline of indigo cultivation around the 20th century was the rise of synthetic alternatives in the international market, which rendered the natural indigo industry obsolete.

question: With reference to the history of India,“Ulgulan” or the Great Tumult is the description of which of the following events? (UPSC Prelims 2020)
option_1: The Revolt of 1857
option_2: The Mappila Rebellion of 1921
option_3: The Indigo Revolt of 1859 – 60
option_4: Birsa Munda’s Revolt of 1899-1900
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • “Ulgulan” or the Great Tumult is the description of the Munda Rebellion, a 19th century tribal rebellion led by Birsa Munda. The rebellion took place in the region south of Ranchi in 1899-1900 and aimed to drive away the British and establish Munda Raj.
  • The rebellion was a response to land encroachment and forced conversion practices. The movement also sought to restore the traditional land rights of thetribals, which had been eroded by British land revenue policies and the activities of Christian missionaries.
  • The tribal population in the region was already reeling under the effects of drought and famine, and was subjected to further exploitation, which led to their disenchantment with the British administration.
  • The Munda Rebellion is also the subject of the 1977 historical fiction novel Aranyer Adhikar (Right to the Forest) by writer activist Mahasweta Devi.

The Indigo Revolt :

  • It is also known as the Indigo Rebellion, was a peasant movement that took place in Bengal in 1859-60. The revolt was a violent rebellion by farmers against the British planters who controlled the indigo industry. The revolt began in the Nadia district in 1859 and spread to other districts in the 1860s.
  • The Indigo Revolt was a result of the British East India Company’s efforts to increase the demand for indigo to make blue cloth in Britain. The British forced farmers to grow indigo, which they received an advance amount for in exchange. However, the advance amount was not enough, leading to increasing debts. The farmers were also forced to grow indigo under unfavorable terms.
  • The revolt was a nonviolent resistance, with the farmers in no possession of arms. The revolt ended in 1860 after the formation of an Indigo commission that offered reforms to the system. The government eventually announced that ryots could not be forced to grow indigo, and planters closed all of their factories. 

The Mappila Rebellion of 1921 :

  • It is also known as the Moplah Rebellion or Malabar Rebellion, was a series of armed revolts by Mappila Muslims in the Malabar region of Kerala, India. The rebellion was a response to British colonial rule and upper caste Hindu landlords. The rebellion began on August 20, 1921 and lasted for over four months.

The rebellion was sparked by a number of factors, including:

1. Religious grievances :

  • The Moplahs were angered by the perceived Hindu domination of the Malabar region. T hey were also alarmed by the growth of Hindu nationalism in India.

2. Oppressive agrarian system :

  • The Mappillas rose against an oppressive agrarian system and fought bravely with crude weapons against a mighty empire.
  • The rebellion was led by Variyamkunnath Kunhamed Haji and Ali Musaliar. The British crushed the rebellion by the end of 1921, raising a special battalion, the Malabar Special Force for the riot.
  • The Mappila movement eventually merged with the ongoing Khilafat agitation. Leaders of the Khilafat-Non-Cooperation Movement such as Gandhi, Shaukat Ali, and Maulana Azad addressed Mappila meetings.

The Revolt of 1857 :

  •   It is also known as the Indian Mutiny, was a widespread but unsuccessful rebellion against the British East India Company in India in 1857–59. The revolt began on May 10, 1857 in Meerut, when Indian soldiers (sepoys) in the British East India Company’s army mutinied against their British commanders. The revolt spread to Delhi, Agra, Kanpur, and Lucknow, and was contained only with the rebels’ defeat in Gwalior on June 20, 1858.

The revolt was caused by many factors, including:

1. Religious and social causes

2. Racism or racial discrimination

3. Exploitation of Indians

4. Interference in religious and cultural affairs

5. Torture of Indians

6. The introduction of the “Enfield” rifle

7. The Doctrine of Lapse, which allowed the British to annex any native state whose ruler died without a male heir

  • The British granted amnesty to all rebels not involved in murder on November 1, 1858, but did not declare the hostilities to have formally ended until July 8, 1859.

question:
In the context of Indian history, the Rakhmabai case of 1884 revolved around............ (UPSC Prelims 2020)

1. Women’s right to gain education

2. Age of consent

3. Restitution of conjugal rights

Select the correct answer using the code given below:
option_1: 1 and 2 only
option_2: 2 and 3 only
option_3: 1 and 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Rakhmabai case of 1884 was a highly publicized trial in India that centered on women’s age of consent, and restitution of conjugal rights.
  • In 1884, Dadaji filed a lawsuit for restitution of conjugal rights after failing to convince Rukhmabai’s family to send her to live with him. Rukhmabai refused to stay with her husband, citing his poverty and poor health.

The court gave her two options:

1. comply or

2. face imprisonment.

  • The case, its appeal, and Rukhmabai’s loss sparked a lot of discussion and controversy in the Indian and international press. Rukhmabai’s defense lawyer was Kashinath Trimbak Telang, a well-known expert on Hindu law who later became a judge of the Bombay High Court. Telang demonstrated in the Court of Appeal that such issues were not legal concerns within Hinduism.
  • Rukhmabai (1864–1955) was an Indian physician and feminist who was the second woman in India to receive a medical degree and practice medicine.

question:
The Gandhi-Irwin Pact included which of the following? (UPSC Prelims 2020)

1. Invitation to Congress to participate in the Round Table Conference

2. Withdrawal of Ordinances promulgated in connection with the Civil Disobedience Movement

3. Acceptance of Gandhi’s suggestion for enquiry into police excesses.

4. Release of only those prisoners who were not charged with violence.

Select the correct answer using the code given below:
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1, 2 and 4 only
option_3: 3 only
option_4: 2, 3 and 4 only
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

The Gandhi-Irwin Pact, signed in 1931, included the following terms:

1. Government :

  • Withdraw all ordinances and end prosecutions. Release all political prisoners, except those guilty of violence. Permit peaceful picketing of liquor and foreign cloth shops. Restore confiscated properties of the satyagrahis.

2. Gandhi :

  • Pledge to give up the satyagraha campaign.

3. Irwin :

  • Agree to release those who had been imprisoned during the campaign and to allow Indians to make salt for domestic use.

4. Indian National Congress (INC) :

  • Agree to take part in the Round Table Conference. Stop the civil disobedience movement.

The pact also included the following features:

1. Withdrawal of all ordinances that curbed the activities of the Congress.

2. Permitting the free collection or manufacture of salt by persons near the seacoast.

question: Wellesley established the Fort William College at Calcutta because............ (UPSC Prelims 2020)
option_1: He was asked by the Board of Directors at London to do so
option_2: He wanted to revive interest in oriental learning in India
option_3: He wanted to provide William Carey and his associates with employment
option_4: He wanted to train British civilians for administrative purpose in India
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Lord Richard Wellesley established the Fort William College in Calcutta in 1800 to train British officials in the vernacular languages and customs of India. The college’s primary goal was to educate British officials in Indian languages to improve administration.
  • The college’s curriculum initially included Persian and other Indian languages, as well as cultural and historical knowledge of India. The curriculum was later expanded to include other subjects such as law, mathematics, and science.
  • Wellesley backdated the statute of foundation to May 4, 1800, to commemorate the first anniversary of his victory over Tipu Sultan at Seringapatam.

question:
With reference to the book “Desher Katha” written by Sakharam Ganesh Deuskar during the freedom struggle, consider the following statement : (UPSC Prelims 2020)

1. It warned against the Colonial States hypnotic conquest of the mind.

2. It inspired the performance of swadeshi street plays and folk songs.

3. The use of ‘desh’ by Deuskar was in the specific context of the region of Bengal.

Which of the statements given above are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2 only
option_2: 2 and 3 only
option_3: 1 and 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Sakharam Ganesh Deuskar’s 1904 political pamphlet Desher Katha (Story of the Nation/Country) warned against the British colonial state’s “hypnotic conquest of the mind”. The book criticized British rule in India and aimed to awaken Indian consciousness and inspire resistance. It also inspired the performance of swadeshi street plays and folk songs.
  • The political pamphlet inspired the performance of swadeshi street plays and folk songs. The book was published in 1904 and is about the British rule in India and the slavery of Indian people. It warned against the colonial state’s hypnotic conquest of the mind.
  • Street plays were a means of protest and mobilization against British rule. Performance artists chose to stage their work on the street to directly confront or engage the public. They also wanted to reach people who couldn’t afford to buy a stage ticket.
  • The Swadeshi movement was formally proclaimed on August 7, 1905, with the passing of the “Boycott” resolution.
  • Deuskar uses “desh” in the context of the whole country to invoke a sense of national identity and unity among all Indians against the British colonial rule, not just those in Bengal.

question: The Vital-Vidhvansak, the first monthly journal to have the untouchable people as its target audience was published by............ (UPSC Prelims 2020)
option_1: Gopal Baba Walangkar
option_2: Jyotiba Phule
option_3: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi
option_4: Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Gopal Baba Walangkar published The Vital-Vidhvansak in 1888. The journal’s title translates to “Destroyer of Brahmanical or Ceremonial Pollution”. The Vital-Vidhvansak was the first monthly journal to target the untouchable population.
  • Walangkar was born into a Mahar caste, which is a scheduled caste. He was a leader of the Mahar Movement in the 19th century, and he also served in the military. He is known for his contributions to social reform and awareness through his journalism and writing. He wrote extensively on social issues in Marathi periodicals and newspapers.

question:
In the first quarter of the seventeenth century, in which of the following was/ were the factory/factories of the English East India Company located? (UPSC Prelims 2021)

1. Broach

2. Chicacole

3. Trichinopoly

Select the correct answer using the code given below.
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1 and 2
option_3: 3 only
option_4: 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • In the first quarter of the 17th century, the English East India Company established factories in Surat, Broach, Ahmedabad, Agra, and Masulipatnam.
  • The first English factory in India was established in Surat, a key port for trading with the Mughals. In 1613, Broach (now Bharuch) became one of the company’s first factories, and was a key center for trade in indigo and cotton textiles. In 1625, the company established another important factory in Chicacole (now Srikakulam).
  • The company was established in 1600 to trade with the East Indies, which included China, Southeast Asia, and the Indian subcontinent. The company’s factories were trading posts and warehouses that also served as political and diplomatic centers. In the early years of the company’s operations, the factories were mainly located on thewest coast of India, particularly in Gujarat and Surat.

question:
Consider the following statements : (UPSC Prelims 2021)

1. The Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms of 1919 recommended granting voting rights to all the women above the age of 21.

2. The Government of India Act of 1935 gave women reserved seats in the legislature.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The statement “The Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms of 1919 recommended granting voting rights to all the women above the age of 21” is incorrect.
  • The Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms, also known as the Government of India Act of 1919, did not recommend granting voting rights to women. Instead, the reforms recommended the creation of a franchise commission to consider the issue of extending the franchise.
  • The 1919 Act’s primary goal was to increase the participation of Indian people in government. The Act also established a Dual System of Government, which split all government-controlled activity into two categories.
  • Government of India Act of 1935 granted women 41 reserved seats in provincial legislatures and limited reservation in central legislatures. The seats were reserved for women on a communal basis, but women could also contest from any general seat.

The Government of India Act of 1935 also:

1. Made 29 million men and 6 million women eligible to vote

2. Established a reserve bank to control the flow of currency in the country

3. Led to the foundation of the federal court in 1937

  • However, the Constitution of India, when promulgated on January 26, 1950, did not have the 1935 Act’s provision for reservation of seats for women.

question: With reference to 8th August 1942 in Indian history, which one of the following statements is correct? (UPSC Prelims 2021)
option_1: The Quit India Resolution was adopted by the AICC.
option_2: The Viceroy’s Executive Council was expanded to include more Indians.
option_3: The Congress ministries resigned in seven provinces.
option_4: Cripps proposed an Indian Union with full Dominion Status once the Second World War was over.
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The All India Congress Committee (AICC) adopted the “Quit India” resolution on August 8, 1942 at its Bombay session.
  • The resolution was moved by Jawaharlal Nehru and seconded by Sardar Patel. The resolution stated that the British must immediately leave India.
  • Mahatma Gandhi launched the “Quit India” movement at the Bombay session of the AICC.
  • The movement demanded an end to British rule in India during World War II. On the same day, Gandhi urged Indians to act as a free nation and follow non-violent civil disobedience.

The movement was caused by:

1. The failure of the Cripps Mission

2. India’s involvement in World War II without prior consultation

3. The prevalence of anti-British sentiment

The movement had the following successes:

1. The rise of future leaders

2. Women’s participation

3. The rise of nationalism

4. The iconic “Quit India” slogan was coined by socialist

5. Congress leader Yusuf Meher Ali in 1942.

  • Statement (b) is incorrect : More Indians were added to Viceroy’s executive council by Government of India Act 1919. First time, an Indian was added in this council by Government of India act 1909.
  •  Statement (c) is incorrect : Congress resigned from ministries in 7 provinces in 1939 as they decided not to support war as India could not be party to a war for democratic freedom while that freedom was being denied to India.
  •  Statement (d) is incorrect : Yes, Cripps proposed a dominion status to India, but this was not related to 8 August 1942.

question: In the context of Colonial India, Shah Nawaz Khan, Prem Kumar Sehgal and Gurbaksh Singh Dhillon are remembered as........... (UPSC Prelims 2021)
option_1: Leaders of Swadeshi and Boycott Movement
option_2: Members of the Interim Government in 1946
option_3: Members of the Drafting Committee in the Constituent Assembly
option_4: Officers of the Indian National Army
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

In the context of Colonial India, Shah Nawaz Khan, Prem Kumar Sehgal, and Gurbaksh Singh Dhillon are all officers of the Indian National Army (INA):

1. Shah Nawaz Khan (1914-1983) :

  • A Major General, politician, and freedom fighter who led INA troops into North-Eastern India.

2. Gurbaksh Singh Dhillon (1914-2006) :

  • An officer who played a key role in the Indian independence movementand was charged with “waging war against His Majesty the King Emperor”.

3. Prem Kumar Sehgal :

  • A colonel who commanded the 2nd Division and led the 2nd Infantry Regiment at Popa.
  • These officers were trusted colleagues of Netaji and were tried in 1945 at the Red Fort in Delhi, the first trial of INA prisoners of war.

question: Who among the following was associated as Secretary with Hindu Female School which later came to be known as Bethune Female School? (UPSC Prelims 2021)
option_1: Annie Besant
option_2: Debendranath Tagore
option_3: Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar
option_4: Sarojini Naidu
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar was the first secretary of the Hindu Female School, which later became known as the Bethune Female School in 1856. Vidyasagar was a government school inspector who promoted education for girls and established institutions for them. He was a pioneer of higher education for women and introduced reforms to improve the quality of education for girls.
  • The Hindu Female School was established in Kolkata in 1849 by John Elliot Drinkwater Bethune. In 1856, the government took charge of the school and renamed it Bethune School in 1856. In 1878, the school was amalgamated with Banga Maha Vidyalaya.

question: With reference to Madanapalle of Andhra Pradesh, which one of the following statements is correct? (UPSC Prelims 2021)
option_1: Pingali Venkayya designed the tricolour Indian National Flag here.
option_2: Pattabhi Sitaramaiah led the Quit India Movement of Andhra region from here
option_3: Rabindranath Tagore translated the National Anthem from Bengali to English here.
option_4: Madame Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott set up headquarters of Theosophical Society first here
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Rabindranath Tagore translated the Bengali national anthem, “Jana Gana Mana,” into English on February 28, 1919 at the Besant Theosophical College in Madanapalle, Andhra Pradesh. Tagore named the English version “The Morning Song of India”.
  • Pingali Venkayya is credited with designing the Indian national flag. Venkayya was a freedom fighter and member of the Indian independence movement. In 1921, he presented his design to Mahatma Gandhi, the leader of the All-India Congress. The Constituent Assembly of India adopted the flag on July 22, 1947.
  • Venkayya was born on August 2, 1876 in Bhatlapenumarru, Andhra Pradesh. He was a teacher, author, agriculturist, linguist, and party member. India observes National Flag Adoption Day on July 22nd each year.
  • Bhogaraju Pattabhi Sitaramayya was a member of the Congress Working Committee when the Quit India Movement began in 1942. He was arrested along with the entire committee and imprisoned for three years without any outside contact in the fort in Ahmednagar, Maharashtra.
  • Madame H. P. Blavatsky and Colonel Henry Steel Olcott founded the Theosophical Society in 1875 and established its headquarters in Adyar, India in 1882.
  • The Theosophical Society is an organization that promotes theosophy, which comes from the Greek word theosophia meaning “God’s wisdom”. The society advocates for a worldwide religion based on Buddhistic and Brahmanic teachings.
  • Blavatsky was a Russian and American author and mystic who became a leading theoretician of Theosophy. Olcott was an American military officer, journalist, lawyer, and Freemason who became the society’s first president.

question: Who among the following is associated with ‘Song from Prison’, a translation of ancient Indian religious lyrics in English? (UPSC Prelims 2021)
option_1: Bal Gangadhar Tilak
option_2: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_3: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi
option_4: Sarojini Naidu
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Quit India Movement planned an all-out campaign to compel British withdrawal from India, after the failure of the Cripps Mission to reach a compromise.
  • At the historic August meeting at Gowalia Tank in Bombay, Gandhi proclaimed his mantra—’do or die’. He was arrested on August 9, 1942.
  • He undertook a 21-day fast in February 1943 to protest against the Government actions against Indians involved in the movement.
  • Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi is associated with the translation of ancient Indian religious lyrics in English, known as Songs from Prison.
  • Gandhi translated the lyrics from Sanskrit hymns and scriptures like the Upanishads while in Yeravda Prison in 1930. John S Hoyland was the other editor of the translation.

question:
With reference to Indian history, consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2022)

1. The Dutch established their factories/ warehouses on the east coast on lands granted to them by Gajapati rulers.

2. Alfonso de Albuquerque captured Goa from the Bijapur Sultanate.

3. The English East India Company established a factory at Madras on a plot of land leased from a representative of the Vijayanagara empire.

Which of the statements given above are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2 only
option_2: 2 and 3 only
option_3: 1 and 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Kapilendra, the minister of Bhanudeva IV (1414-1435), usurped the throne in 1435 and laid the foundation of the Gajapati rule in Odisha. After Pratapa Rudra’s death (1540), his successors could hardly hold the empire intact, and the end of Suryavamsi (Gajapati) dynasty came soon after (1542), whereas the Dutch East India Company was formed in 1602 through a charter.
  • Albuquerque acquired Goa from the Sultan of Bijapur in 1510 with ease; the principal port of the Sultan of Bijapur became “the first bit of Indian territory to be under the Europeans since the time of Alexander the Great”.
  • The English east india company established a factory in Madras (1639) on land leased from a representative of the Vijayanagara empire called The Nayakas.

question:
Consider the following freedom fighters: (UPSC Prelims 2022)

1. Barindra Kumar Ghosh

2. Jogesh Chandra Chatterjee

3. Rash Behari Bose

Who of the above was/were actively associated with the Ghadar Party?
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: 2 only
option_3: 1 and 3
option_4: 3 only
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Ghadar revolutionaries were primarily based in the United States, especially in San Francisco, Vancouver, and New York. They also had branches along the US Coast and in the far East.
  • The Ghadar revolutionaries, also known as the Ghadar Party, were inspired by anti colonialist and nationalist ideas. They were Punjabi immigrants who had settled in theUS and Canada. The Ghadar Party’s goal was to overthrow British rule in India and establish a socialist republic.

Some key members of the Ghadar Party include:

1. Lala Har Dayal

2. Sant Baba Wasakha Singh Dadehar

3. Baba Jawala Singh

4. Santokh Singh

5. Sohan Singh

6. Bhakna Ras Behari Bose

  • The Ghadar Party was initially called the Pacific Coast Hindustan Association and was formed in the United States on July 15, 1913. The Ghadar Party’s headquarters were located at 436 Hill St, San Francisco, California in the Yugantar Ashram building. The Ghadar Party’s newspaper, Ghadar, was published to spread awareness about British rule in India. In 1915, the Ghadar Party organized a failed uprising in India.
  • Barindra Kumar Ghosh was associated with a revolutionary group called Jugantar and Jogesh Chatterjee was associated with the Hindustan Republican Association/ Army (HRA).

question:
With reference to the proposals of Cripps Mission, consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2022)

1. The Constituent Assembly would have members nominated by the Provincial Assemblies as well as the Princely States.

2. Any Province, which is not prepared to accept the new Constitution would have the right to sign a separate agreement with Britain regarding its future status.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

The correct option is (b) 2 only. 

Statement 1 is incorrect. 

  • The Cripps Mission proposed that the Constituent Assembly would be composed of members who were partly elected by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies (through proportional representation) and partly nominated by the rulers of the Princely States. The statement incorrectly says that both provincial and princely state members would be nominated.

Statement 2 is correct. 

  • A key proposal of the Cripps Mission was that any province not willing to accept the new constitution would have the right to opt out. It could either retain its existing constitutional position or negotiate a separate agreement with Britain point of major contention and was seen as a "blueprint for India's partition".

question: By which one of the following Acts was the Governor General of Bengal designated as the Governor General of India? (UPSC Prelims 2023)
option_1: The Regulating Act
option_2: The Pitt’s India Act
option_3: The Charter Act of 1793
option_4: The Charter Act of 1833
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Charter Act of 1833 renamed the Governor-General of Bengal as the Governor-General of India. The act also gave the Governor-General of India all civil and military powers.
  • The Charter Act of 1833 was the result of the Industrial Revolution in England. It was also the final step towards centralization in British India.
  • The act replaced the governor-general and Council of Fort William with the governor general and Council of India. William Bentick was the first Governor-General of British India.

Some of its provisions include:

1. Law Commission: Established a Law Commission to codify and consoli date Indian laws. The first Law Com mission was appointed in 1834 and consisted of five members, including Lord T.B. Macually as chairman.

2. Governor-General: The gover nor-general in India was the same as the governor-general in Bengal. Lord William Bentinck became the first Governor-General of India.

3. Legislative abilities: The adminis trations of Bombay and Madras were drained of their legislative abilities.

4. Abolition of Slavery: The Charter Act of 1833 ensured the decline of slavery in British India.

5. British East India Company: The act ended the commercial activities of the British East India Company and made it a purely administrative body.

6. Trade relations: The act suspended trade relations with China.

7. Laws: The act mandated that all laws enacted in India be submitted to the British Parliament.

8. British colonization: The act legal ized the British colonization of the country.

9. English settlement: The act permit ted the English to settle freely in In dia.

question: With reference to the Indian History, Alexander Rea, A. H. Longhurst, Robert Sewell, James Burgess and Walter Elliot were associated with........... (UPSC Prelims 2023)
option_1: Achaeological excavations
option_2: Establishment of English Press in Colonial India
option_3: Establishment of Churches in Princely States
option_4: construction of railways in Colonial India
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Alexander Rea, A. H. Longhurst, Robert Sewell, James Burgess, and Walter Elliot were all archaeological surveyors in India during British rule. They are associated with archaeological excavations in India, including the Ajanta Caves, the Ellora Caves, and the Hampi ruins. Their work has helped to shed light on the history and culture of India.

Here’s some more information about some of these people:

1. Alexander Rea: A British (Scottish) archaeologist and photographer who arrived in India in 1882 and became Assistant of Burgess in the A.S.I., Madras Division, from 1886.

2. Albert Henry Longhurst: A British archaeologist and art historian who worked in India and Ceylon.

3. Robert Sewell: The Keeper of the Madras Record Office who was responsible for documenting ancientinscriptions and remains in the region.

question:
Consider the following statements : (UPSC Prelims 2023)

Statement I: 7th August is declared as the National Handloom Day.

Statement-II : It was in 1905 that the Swadeshi Movement was launched on the same day.

Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above· statements?
option_1: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement I.
option_2: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct and Statement II is not the correct explanation for Statement I.
option_3: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
option_4: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Both Statement I and Statement II are correct and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement I.
  • August 7 was chosen as the National Handloom Day to commemorate the Swadeshi Movement which was launched on this day in 1905 in the Calcutta Town hall to protest against the partition of Bengal by the British Government.

question:
With reference to India, consider the following pairs: (UPSC Prelims 2023)

 

Action

The Act under which it is covered

1.

Unauthorized wearing of police or military uniforms

under  The Official Secrets Act, 1923

 

 2.

Knowingly      misleading: or otherwise interfering with a police officer or military officer when engaged in their duties 

 under  The Indian Evidence Act, 1872

3.

Celebratory gunfire which can endanger the personal safety of others    

under The Arms (Amendment) Act, 2019

How many of the above pairs are correctly matched?
option_1: Only one
option_2: Only two
option_3: All Three
option_4: None
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Official Secrets Act of 1923 is an anti-espionage law in India that dates back to the British colonial era. The act prohibits actions that support an enemy state’s attack against India and prohibits access to restricted government sites or authority. It also makes spying, sharing secret information, and unauthorized use of uniforms punishable offenses.
  • The act states that actions that help an enemy state against India are strongly condemned. It also states that one cannot approach, inspect, or even pass over a prohibited government site or area.
  • The act provides the framework for dealing with espionage, sedition, and other potential threats to the integrity of the nation. If found guilty, a person may get up to 14 years’ imprisonment, a fine, or both.
  • The Indian Evidence Act of 1872 is a set of rules that govern the admissibility of evidence in Indian courts. It was originally passed by the Imperial Legislative Council in 1872, during the British Raj.

The Act recognizes several types of evidence, including:

1. Oral testimony, Documentary evidence, Physical evidence.

2. The Act also states that any information contained in an electronic record is admissible in legal proceedings, without the need for the original device.

The Act is important for a number of reasons, including:

1. It guarantees that only credible and admissible proof is given in court.

2. It protects the rights of witnesses and accused by defining the circumstances under which they can be forced to testify.

Some of the cardinal principles of the law of evidence include:

1. Evidence must be confined to the matter in issue.

2. Hearsay evidence must not be admitted.

3. Best evidence must be given in all cases.

  • The Arms (Amendment) Act, 2019 ensures that those using firearms in a rash or negligent manner in celebratory gunfire, endangering human life or personal safety of others, shall be punishable with an imprisonment to two years or with fine which may extend to Rs one lakh or with both.

question:
With reference to revenue collection by Cornwallis, consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2024)

1. Under the Ryotwari Settlement of revenue collection, the peasants were exempted from revenue payment in case of bad harvests or natural calamities.

2. Under the Permanent Settlement in Bengal, if the Zamindar failed to pay his revenues to the state, on or before the fixed date, he would be removed from his Zamindari.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Under the Ryotwari Settlement of revenue collection, peasants were not exempted from revenue payment in case of bad harvests or natural calamities. Hence, statement 1 is not correct.
  • Permanent settlement was designed by John Shore & implemented by Lord Cornwallis in 1793. In permanent settlement revenue was fixed at 45% of the produce of which 10/11th share was fixed for the Company & 1/11th share went to Zamindars. This amount to be paid was fixed permanently.
  • Under the Sunset Law 1793, If a Zamindar failed to pay revenue in the British to state on time, he would be removed from his zamindari. Hence, statement 2 is correct.

question:
With reference to the Government of India Act, 1935, consider the following statements : (UPSC Prelims 2024)

1. It provided for the establishment of an All India Federation based on the union of the British Indian Provinces and Princely States.

2. Defence and Foreign Affairs were kept under the control of the federal legislature.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

The correct answer is (a) 1 only.

  • The Government of India Act, 1935 was the most comprehensive constitutional reform introduced by the British in colonial India before independence. It indeed provided for the establishment of an All India Federation, which was to be based on the union of British Indian provinces and the princely states. However, this federation never actually came into existence because the princely states did not agree to join it. Therefore, statement 1 is correct.
  • On the other hand, statement 2 is incorrect because under the Act, Defence and Foreign Affairs were not under the control of the federal legislature. These subjects were considered “reserved subjects” and remained under the direct control of the Governor-General, who was responsible to the British government, not to the legislature. The federal legislature had limited powers, and key matters like defence, external affairs, and ecclesiastical affairs remained beyond its jurisdiction.

question:
Consider the following pairs : (UPSC Prelims 2024)

 

Party

Its Leader

1.

Bharatiya Jana Sangh

Dr.Shyama Prasad Mukherjee

2.

Socialist Party

C. Rajagopalachari

3.

Congress for Democracy

Jagjivan Ram

4.

Swatantra Party

Acharya Narendra Dev

How many of the above are correctly matched?
option_1: Only one
option_2: Only two
option_3: Only three
option_4: All four
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Bharatiya Jana Sangh - Syama Prasad Mukherjee- 1951. Hence, pair 1 is correctly matched.
  • The Socialist Party -Jai Prakash Narayan, Ram Manohar Lohia, and Acharya Narendra Dev-1934 Hence, pair 2 is not correctly matched.
  • Congress for Democracy (CFD) - Jagjivan Ram -1977. Hence, pair 3 is correctly matched.
  • Swatantra Party - C Rajagopalachari, Minoo Masani and N G Ranga -1959. Hence, pair4 is not correctly matched
  •  Therefore only two pairs are correctly matched. Hence, Option (b) is correct.

question:
Consider the following statements about Raja Ram Mohan Roy: (UPSC Prelims 2025)

I. He possessed great love and respect for the traditional philosophical systems of the East.

II. He desired his countrymen to accept the rational and scientific approach and the principle of human dignity and social equality of all men and women.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
option_1: I only
option_2: II only
option_3: Both I and II
option_4: Neither I nor II
solution_text:
Explanation: (c) Both I and II

  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy had deep respect for India's ancient philosophical traditions, particularly Vedanta philosophy, and drew inspiration from texts like the Upanishads.
  • He was a reformer who strongly advocated for rational thinking, scientific outlook, and social reforms like the abolition of Sati, promotion of women's rights, and equality. His work was rooted in the principles of human dignity and equality, consistent with Enlightenment values.

question:
Consider the following subjects with regard to the Non-Cooperation Programme: (UPSC Prelims 2025)

I. Boycott of law-courts and foreign cloth

II. Observance of strict non-violence

III. Retention of titles and honours without using them in public

IV. Establishment of Panchayats for settling disputes

How many of the above were parts of the Non-Cooperation Programme?
option_1: Only one
option_2: Only two
option_3: Only three
option_4: All the four
solution_text:
Explanation: (c) Only three

  • Boycott of law-courts and foreign cloth was a major component of the Non-Cooperation Movement launched in 1920.
  • Non-violence (Ahimsa) was strictly emphasized by Gandhi throughout the movement.
  • The programme demanded surrender of titles and honours, not their retention.
  • Gandhi encouraged the formation of Panchayats to settle disputes outside colonial courts as part of Swaraj.

question:
Consider the following statements in respect of the Non-Cooperation Movement: (UPSC Prelims 2025)

I. The Congress declared the attainment of 'Swaraj' by all legitimate and peaceful means to be its objective.

II. It was to be implemented in stages with civil disobedience and non-payment of taxes for the next stage only if 'Swaraj' did not come within a year and the Government resorted to repression.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
option_1: I only
option_2: II only
option_3: Both I and II
option_4: Neither I nor II
solution_text:
Explanation: (c) Both I and II

  • The Non-Cooperation Movement aimed at achieving 'Swaraj' (self-rule) through peaceful and legitimate means. The strategy was to proceed in phases, initially through non-cooperation with the British government. If 'Swaraj' was not granted within a year and the government resorted to repression, more assertive actions like civil disobedience and non-payment of taxes were to be adopted in the subsequent stage.

question: "Sedition has become my religion" was the famous statement given by Gandhiji at the time of: (UPSC Prelims 2025)
option_1: The Champaran Satyagraha
option_2: Publicly violating Salt Law at Dandi
option_3: Attending the Second Round Table Conference in London
option_4: The launch of the Quit India Movement
solution_text:
Explanation: (b) Publicly violating Salt Law at Dandi

  • The famous statement "Sedition has become my religion" was made by Mahatma Gandhi on 6th April 1930 at Dandi, when he broke the Salt Law as part of the Civil Disobedience Movement.
  • This act marked a symbolic rejection of British authority and galvanized nationwide protests.

Gandhi Ji declared :

  • "The British rule in India has brought about moral, material, cultural and spiritual ruination of this great country. I regard this rule as a curse. I am ought to destroy this system of Government... Sedition has become my religion. Ours is a non-violent battle. We are not to kill anybody but it is our dharma to see that the curse of this Government is blotted out

question: Who provided legal defence to the people arrested in the aftermath of Chauri Chaura incident? (UPSC Prelims 2025)
option_1: C. R. Das
option_2: Madan Mohan Malaviya and Krishna Kant
option_3: Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew and Khwaja Hasan Nizami
option_4: M. A. Jinnah
solution_text:
Explanation: (b) Madan Mohan Malaviya and Krishna Kant

  • The Chauri Chaura incident occurred on February 4, 1922, in a town in Uttar Pradesh. During a protest against British colonial rule, a violent clash took place between protesters and police. The protesters set fire to a police station, resulting in the death of 22 policemen.
  • Following the incident, the British authorities arrested many protestors and charged them with serious offenses. Madan Mohan Malaviya and Krishna Kant provided legal defense to the accused in the subsequent trials

question: Subsequent to which one of the following events, Gandhiji, who consistently opposed untouchability and appealed for its eradication from all spheres, decided to include the upliftment of 'Harijans' in his political and social programme? (UPSC Prelims 2025)
option_1: The Poona Pact
option_2: The Gandhi-Irwin Agreement (Delhi Pact)
option_3: Arrest of Congress leadership at the time of the Quit India Movement
option_4: Promulgation of the Government of India Act, 1935
solution_text:
Explanation: (a) The Poona Pact

  • The Poona Pact was signed in 1932 between Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
  • It was a result of negotiations after the British government announced separate electorates for the "Depressed Classes" (now called Scheduled Castes) under the Communal Award.
  • Gandhi opposed separate electorates for Harijans, fearing it would divide the Hindu community.
  • During his fast unto death in Yerwada Jail to protest the separate electorates, the Poona Pact was negotiated, which provided reserved seats for Harijans in the general electorate instead.

question:
Consider the following fruits: (UPSC Prelims 2025)

I. Papaya

II. Pineapple

III. Guava

How many of the above were introduced in India by the Portuguese in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries?
option_1: Only one
option_2: Only two
option_3: All the three
option_4: None
solution_text:
Explanation: (c) All the three

  • Papaya, pineapple, and guava are all believed to have been introduced to India by the Portuguese during the 16th and 17th centuries.
  • The Portuguese, through their extensive maritime trade and colonization, brought various New World crops to India.
  • Papaya originated in Central America, pineapple in South America, and guava in the tropical regions of the Americas.

question: Who among the following was the founder of the 'Self-Respect Movement'? (UPSC Prelims 2025)
option_1: 'Periyar' E. V. Ramaswamy Naicker
option_2: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar
option_3: Bhaskarrao Jadhav
option_4: Dinkarrao Javalkar
solution_text:
Explanation: (a) 'Periyar' E. V. Ramaswamy Naicker

  • 'Periyar' E. V. Ramaswamy Naicker founded the Self-Respect Movement in 1925 in Tamil Nadu.
  • The movement aimed to promote self-respect and fight against caste discrimination and social inequality.
  • It challenged the Brahminical social order and sought to empower the non-Brahmin communities.
  • The movement also advocated for rationalism, women's rights, and the abolition of caste-based discrimination.
